focus_skills: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments
questions.question: A school administration wanted to assess student opinions about a new lunch menu. The administration surveyed a sample of 100 students in the school cafeteria during lunch time. The survey showed that the majority of those sampled liked the new menu. Which of the following is true about the school's survey?

options.A: It shows that the majority of all students in the school like the new menu.
options.B: The survey sample should have included more students who eat in the cafeteria.
options.C: The survey sample should have consisted entirely of students who do not eat in the cafeteria.
options.D: The survey sample is biased because it is not representative of all students in the school.

questions.explanation: The survey was conducted only among students in the cafeteria during lunch, who may have different opinions from students who eat elsewhere or bring their own lunch. This introduces sampling bias, making the sample not representative of all students.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for potential sources of bias in the sampling method, such as location or group selection, when evaluating survey validity.

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments
questions.question: A researcher selected 150 people at random from a group of people who indicated that they enjoyed a particular video game. The 150 people were shown an expansion pack for the game and then asked whether they liked or disliked it. Of those surveyed, 85% said they liked the expansion. Which of the following inferences can appropriately be drawn from this survey result?

options.A: At least 85% of people who play video games will like this expansion.
options.B: At least 85% of people who buy expansion packs will like this one.
options.C: Most people who dislike this video game will dislike the expansion.
options.D: Most people who like this video game will like the expansion.

questions.explanation: The sample was drawn from people who liked the original game, so the results can only be generalized to that group, indicating that most who like the game will like the expansion.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When drawing inferences, ensure they are limited to the population from which the sample was selected.

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments
questions.question: Residents of a city were surveyed to determine whether they are satisfied with public transportation. A random sample of 300 residents was selected. All 300 responded, and 85% said they are satisfied. Based on this information, which of the following statements must be true? I. Of all the city residents, 85% would say they are satisfied with public transportation. II. If another random sample of 300 residents were surveyed, 85% would say they are satisfied.
questions.explanation: Sample results approximate the population but do not guarantee exact matches, and different samples can vary.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that sample statistics are estimates and subject to sampling variability; they do not prove exact population parameters.

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments
questions.question: A survey was conducted using a sample of math teachers selected at random from Texas public schools. The teachers surveyed were asked to name the publishers of their current curricula. What is the largest population to which the results of the survey can be generalized?

options.A: All teachers in the United States
options.B: All math teachers in the United States
options.C: All math teachers at Texas public schools
options.D: All teachers at Texas public schools

questions.explanation: The random sample was drawn from math teachers in Texas public schools, so results generalize only to that population.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Generalization is limited to the specific population sampled; broader groups may differ.

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments
questions.question: A polling agency surveyed 800 adults selected at random from a medium-sized town and asked, “Are you satisfied with the local parks?” Of those surveyed, 75% said they were satisfied. Based on the results, which statements must be true? 1. Of all adults in the town, 75% are satisfied with the local parks. 2. If another 800 adults from the town were surveyed, 75% would say they are satisfied. 3. If 800 adults from a different town were surveyed, 75% would say they are satisfied.
questions.explanation: None must be true due to sampling variability and differences between populations.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Distinguish between what is likely based on a sample and what must be true; account for variability.

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments
questions.question: A sample of 50 sixth-grade students was selected at random from a particular school. The 50 students completed a survey about school uniforms, and 40 thought they were a good idea. Which of the following is the largest population to which the results of the survey can be applied?

options.B: All sixth-grade students at the school
options.D: All sixth-grade students in the district where the school is located

questions.explanation: The random sample was from sixth-graders at the school, so results apply to that population.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the exact population sampled to determine the scope of generalization.

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments
questions.question:
A basketball coach wanted to study the relationship between the number of practice hours per week and points scored in games. The coach selected 60 teams at random from all teams in a regional league. The table shows data for the 45 teams in the sample that practiced at least 4 hours per week.

Hours practiced | 8 to 10 points | 11 or more points | Total
4 to 6 hours | 5 | 10 | 15
More than 6 hours | 8 | 22 | 30
Total | 13 | 32 | 45

Which of the following is the largest population to which the results of the study can be generalized?

options.A: All teams in the league that scored 11 or more points per game
options.C: The 45 teams in the sample that practiced at least 4 hours per week
options.D: All teams in the regional league

questions.explanation: The sample was randomly selected from all teams in the league, allowing generalization to the entire league.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the sampling method and original population, not subsets of the data presented.

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments
questions.question: A nutritionist designed and conducted a study to determine whether a specific diet improves concentration in high school students. For the study, the nutritionist chose a random sample of 40 students from all of the students at one high school in a large district. The nutritionist found that students on the diet showed significant improvement. What is the largest group to which the results of the study can be generalized?

options.B: All students at the high school
options.C: All high school students in the district

questions.explanation: The random sample was from one specific high school, limiting generalization to that school's students.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Generalize only to the population directly sampled; larger groups require broader sampling.

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments
questions.question: Near the end of a radio talk show, the host invited listeners to call in and vote on whether they support a proposed local tax increase. At the end of the show, the host reported that 60% supported the increase and 38% opposed it. Which of the following best explains why the results are unlikely to represent the sentiments of the local population?

options.A: The percentages do not add up to 100%, so the conclusions are invalid.
options.B: Those who called in were not a random sample of the local population.
options.C: There were not equal percentages for support and opposition.
options.D: The show did not provide enough time for all listeners to call in.

questions.explanation: Call-in polls are self-selected, not random, and may not represent the broader population.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recognize self-selection bias in voluntary response samples.

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: Observational studies and experiments
questions.question: To determine the mean annual income per household in a town, a researcher surveyed 25 households at a local shopping mall on a weekday afternoon. For the 25 households surveyed, the mean income was $60,000. Which of the following statements must be true?

options.A: The mean annual income per household in the town is $60,000.
options.B: A determination about the mean income per household in the town should not be made because the sample size is too small.
options.C: The sampling method is flawed and may produce a biased estimate of the mean income per household in the town.
options.D: The sampling method is not flawed and is likely to produce an unbiased estimate of the mean income per household in the town.

questions.explanation: Surveying at a mall on a weekday may bias toward certain income groups, not representing all households.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Evaluate sampling locations and times for potential biases in representation.

questions.skill: Linear equations in 1 variable
questions.question: If <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 5 to both sides: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></math>. Divide by 4: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable by performing inverse operations step by step.

questions.skill: Linear functions
questions.question: What is the slope of the line given by the equation <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Rewrite in slope-intercept form: <math><mn>-6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, slope is <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> or 0.5.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Convert equations to slope-intercept form to identify the slope easily.

questions.skill: Nonlinear equations in 1 variable
questions.question: What is the positive solution to the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, solutions x=7, x=-1. Positive is 7.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use factoring or quadratic formula for nonlinear equations, and verify solutions.

questions.skill: Area and volume formulas
questions.question: The base of a triangle is 8 units and the height is 5 units. What is the area of the triangle?
questions.explanation: <math><mi>Area</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mi>base</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>height</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall basic area formulas and apply them directly to given dimensions.

questions.skill: Percentages
questions.question: An investment of $200 increases by 15% and then decreases by 10%. What is the final value of the investment?
questions.explanation: First: <math><mn>200</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1.15</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>230</mn></math>. Then: <math><mn>230</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>207</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Calculate successive percentage changes step by step, using the updated value each time.

questions.skill: Nonlinear functions
questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math> is graphed in the xy-plane. What are the coordinates of the vertex of the graph?
questions.explanation: The vertex form <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math> gives vertex (h, k) = (3, 4).
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the vertex directly from the vertex form of quadratic functions.

questions.skill: Right triangles and trigonometry
questions.question: In a right triangle, the legs measure 5 units and 12 units. What is the length of the hypotenuse?
questions.explanation: By Pythagorean theorem: <math><msqrt><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>25</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>144</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>169</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Apply the Pythagorean theorem for right triangles to find missing sides.

questions.skill: Two-variable data: models and scatter-plots
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='380' y2='250' stroke='black'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='20' stroke='black'/><text x='370' y='270' font-family='sans-serif'>x</text><text x='30' y='40' font-family='sans-serif'>y</text><line x1='125' y1='250' x2='125' y2='255' stroke='black'/><text x='115' y='270' font-size='10' font-family='sans-serif'>100</text><line x1='200' y1='250' x2='200' y2='255' stroke='black'/><text x='190' y='270' font-size='10' font-family='sans-serif'>200</text><line x1='275' y1='250' x2='275' y2='255' stroke='black'/><text x='265' y='270' font-size='10' font-family='sans-serif'>300</text><line x1='50' y1='175' x2='45' y2='175' stroke='black'/><text x='20' y='180' font-size='10' font-family='sans-serif'>100</text><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='45' y2='100' stroke='black'/><text x='20' y='105' font-size='10' font-family='sans-serif'>200</text><circle cx='125' cy='100' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='200' cy='137' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='275' cy='175' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='350' cy='212' r='4' fill='black'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot showing four points decreasing from left to right. The axes are labeled with ticks indicating the scale. The points align with coordinates roughly at (100, 200), (200, 150), (300, 100), and (400, 50).
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between two variables <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>. Which of the following equations best models the trend in the data?
questions.explanation: The points <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>200</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>200</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>150</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>300</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>400</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>)</mo></math> suggest a line with slope <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.5</mn></math> and y-intercept around <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>250</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='380' y2='250' stroke='black'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='20' stroke='black'/><text x='370' y='270' font-family='sans-serif'>x</text><text x='30' y='40' font-family='sans-serif'>y</text><line x1='125' y1='250' x2='125' y2='255' stroke='black'/><text x='115' y='270' font-size='10' font-family='sans-serif'>100</text><line x1='200' y1='250' x2='200' y2='255' stroke='black'/><text x='190' y='270' font-size='10' font-family='sans-serif'>200</text><line x1='275' y1='250' x2='275' y2='255' stroke='black'/><text x='265' y='270' font-size='10' font-family='sans-serif'>300</text><line x1='50' y1='175' x2='45' y2='175' stroke='black'/><text x='20' y='180' font-size='10' font-family='sans-serif'>100</text><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='45' y2='100' stroke='black'/><text x='20' y='105' font-size='10' font-family='sans-serif'>200</text><circle cx='125' cy='100' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='200' cy='137' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='275' cy='175' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='350' cy='212' r='4' fill='black'/><line x1='50' y1='62.5' x2='350' y2='212.5' stroke='blue' stroke-dasharray='5,5' stroke-width='2'/><text x='150' y='285' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' fill='blue'>y = -0.5x + 250</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Scatterplot with a dashed blue trend line passing through the points, illustrating the model y = -0.5x + 250.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Estimate slope and intercept from key points in scatterplots to select the best model.

questions.skill: Lines, angles, and triangles
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='200' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='100' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='100' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='190,250 190,240 200,240' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='45' y='265'>A</text><text x='195' y='90'>B</text><text x='345' y='265'>C</text><text x='195' y='270'>D</text><text x='170' y='160' font-size='12'>50°</text><text x='210' y='160' font-size='12'>x°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle ABC with base AC, point D on AC, BD perpendicular to AC, angle ABD 50 degrees, find x = angle CBD
questions.question: In the figure, BD is perpendicular to AC, and the measure of angle ABD is 50°. What is the value of x?
questions.explanation: Since BD is perpendicular to AC, angles ADB and CDB are 90°. In triangle ABD, the angles sum to 180°, the angle at D is 90°, and the angle at B is 50°, so the angle at A is 40°. Since triangle ABC is isosceles with AB = BC, the base angles at A and C are equal, each 40°. In triangle CBD, the angle at C is 40°, the angle at D is 90°, so the angle at B (x) is 50°.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='200' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='100' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='100' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='190,250 190,240 200,240' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='45' y='265'>A</text><text x='195' y='90'>B</text><text x='345' y='265'>C</text><text x='195' y='270'>D</text><text x='170' y='160' font-size='12' fill='red'>50°</text><text x='210' y='160' font-size='12' fill='blue'>x = 50°</text><text x='140' y='100' font-size='12' fill='grey'>AB = BC</text><text x='70' y='245'>40°</text><text x='320' y='245'>40°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Annotated figure showing base angles of 40 degrees each in triangles ABD and CBD
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use perpendicular lines to create right triangles and calculate angles using triangle sum.

questions.skill: Equivalent expressions
questions.question: Which of the following is equivalent to <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>16</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> for <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>4</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor the numerator: <math><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> = <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Factor numerators and cancel common factors to simplify rational expressions.
